title: Probe metadata element schema
description: Probe metadata element schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.54

propertyDescriptions.probeHemisphere: Brain hemisphere where probe was located in.
propertyDescriptions.associatedBrainRegionID: Identifier of the associated brain region based on BIRNLEX ontology.
propertyDescriptions.associatedBrainRegion: Textual indication of the location of the probe in the brain.
propertyDescriptions.associatedBrainRegionQualityType: The method used to identify the associated brain region (estimated|proof) depending on anatomical pictures proofing the location or indirect estimation of the location.
propertyDescriptions.referenceAtlas: Reference atlas used for associated brain region
propertyDescriptions.hasReferenceSpace: The reference space used for the coordinate definition, could be, ‘anatomical’ , ‘recording chamber’, ‘sample’, ‘other’.
propertyDescriptions.anatomicalAxesOrientation: If anatomical reference space was used, then the corresponding anatomical axes orienatation. for instance, AIL would mean X, Y, Z axes are oriented towards anterior, inferior and left, respectively.
propertyDescriptions.probeRoll: Recorded rotation around the roll axis.
propertyDescriptions.probePitch: Recorded rotation around the pitch axis.
propertyDescriptions.probeYaw: Recorded rotation around the yaw axis.
propertyDescriptions.placementPicture: Relative or absolute path to photograph showing probe placement.
propertyDescriptions.probeManufacturer: Manufacturer of the probe system, eg., ‘opnephys’,’blackrock’, etc.
propertyDescriptions.probeDeviceSerialNumber: Manufacturer provided serial number of the probe.
propertyDescriptions.probeID: Unique identifier for each electrophysiological recording probe that is referenced in the dataset.
propertyDescriptions.probeType: Type of probe used – Utah array, laminar, single tetrode, etc.

schema:name: Probe Metadata
schema:description: Probes are physical devices used for recording the electrophysiological data. They can be permanently implanted (chronic recordings) or inserted just for the recording (acute recordings).
